The 2024 Minnesota Democratic presidential primary took place on March 5, 2024, as part of the Democratic Party primaries for the 2024 presidential election. 92 delegates to the Democratic National Convention were allocated to presidential candidates. The contest was held on Super Tuesday alongside primaries in 14 other states and territories.
Biden won the primary by a large margin, though "Uncommitted" earned a significant number of votes and 11 delegates. After a landslide loss in his home state, Dean Philips dropped out of the race and endorsed Biden.
Candidates
The following candidates were submitted to the SOS by DFL Chair Ken Martin:
* Joe Biden
* Eban Cambridge
* Gabriel Cornejo
* Frankie Lozada
* Jason Palmer
* Armando "Mando" Perez-Serrato
* Dean Phillips
* Cenk Uygur
* Marianne Williamson
* Uncommitted
Additionally, uncommitted appeared on the ballot, which many chose as a protest vote.
Endorsements
* Tina Smith, U.S. senator from Minnesota (2018–present), 48th lieutenant governor of Minnesota (2015–2018)
U.S. representatives
* Angie Craig, U.S. representative from  (2019–present)
* Ilhan Omar, U.S. representative from  (2019–present)

* Tim Walz, governor of Minnesota (2019–present); U.S. representative for  (2007–2019)
Party officials
* Ken Martin, chair of the Minnesota Democratic–Farmer–Labor Party (2011–present), vice chair of the Democratic National Committee (2021–present)
}}

*Azrin Awal, Duluth City Councilor at-large (2022–present)

*Wendy Durrwachter, Duluth City Councilor from District 1 (2024–present)
*Mitra Jalali, Saint Paul City Councilmember from Ward 4 (2018–present), city council president (2024–present)
*Nelsie Yang, Saint Paul City Councilmember from Ward 6 (2020–present)

*National organization and Twin Cities chapter of the Democratic Socialists of America
*Jewish Voice for Peace Action

Results
Source:
Results by congressional district
Biden carried all the state's eight congressional districts. He recorded his best result in the eighth district while underperforming heavily in the urban fifth district. It is represented by progressive Democrat Ilhan Omar, who supported a ceasefire in the Gaza war, but backed Biden in the primary.
The district saw almost a third of votes cast for uncommitted.
Phillips trailed considerably, but managed to earn a higher result than uncommitted in the third (which he represents in Congress) and seventh districts.
Meanwhile, Williamson performed poorly, with the strongest showing of just 1.88% in the seventh district.
